text:
Agree with everything so far.

Will also add that we've seen an increase in social media engagement, from other people posting our content to their audience. If you create something shareworthy, get found by Google, then make it easy for people to share, our social engagement shot up in line with our organic traffic.

You should also ask if you're on the right platforms? We have Twitter, LinkedIn, and Facebook. Because they're big and you should, right? However, we get a lot of engagement from Reddit and niche forums.

text: Hey Dom, yes, we get more engagement on Reddit, Quora and LinkedIn groups as compared to Twitter and FB. So that’s where we post. But I think relooking what we post and tweaking it is never a bad idea. :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Hey Dom, yes, we get more engagement on Reddit, Quora and LinkedIn groups as compared to Twitter and FB. So that’s where we post. But I think relooking what we post and tweaking it is never a bad idea.

text:
Hey <@URAV154AV>, great points!
Yes we have done this mapping. We have nurture flows set up, and we have some high-quality content for each persona & stage. But I guess taking another look at the content itself and its usefulness (maybe even update it for current times like <@U0113AV4895> said) is a good area to work on.
Thanks folks!

text: Great feedback, something a lot of people sleep on when looking at right platforms and promotion (as highlighted above) is tapping into  other peoples owned channels in your sector. Is there a succesful publisher? A go to youtube channel or podcast? Likely all getting much more traffic and engagement right now and might be worth looking into collaborations with them or paid promotions to extended your campaigns further.

text: My CEO approved a $2K reoccurring monthly budget for content promotion. Curious to see how seasoned content managers would allocate it. My thoughts are to use FB ads and contract a video editor and FB ad specialist to set up the ads and write copy for the next 6 months. But I want to make sure I'm not overlooking any other options for content promotion.

text: Like I have some really highly ranked posts that are essentially the answer to what to do when you get a particular error message in an app. You _could_ try to do content promotion around that but it makes more sense to just sit back and let the organic search come in on it.

text:
yeah this is the piece <@UJE5LARL0> mentioned: <https://www.animalz.co/blog/library-vs-publication/>

totally agree with <@UJG24P8P6> too - different types of content serve different purposes: <https://www.animalz.co/blog/diversified-content-portfolio/>

my 2c on promotion too, the highest-leverage think you can do is invest more time upfront in the article itself, tailoring it to a very specific distribution channel - search, or a community, or a newsletter, or Hacker News/Reddit/etc: <https://www.animalz.co/blog/content-promotion/>

it's really easy to think of content promotion as this post-hoc problem - I have this article, how do I distribute it?

the better tack is almost always starting with the distribution question: where do I want to distribute it, and how should I shape it to the specific nuances of that channel?

hopefully you'll forgive the link-dropping - these are just articles I wrote in response to this exact question :sweat_smile:

text: Hello hello. We're in the process of completely revamping our ebook landing pages (starting with this guy: <https://go.roadmunk.com/agile-roadmap-ebook>). If you're reading this and have any advice, examples of ebook landing pages that stuck with you or "best practice" guides, please share :slightly_smiling_face:

text: Has anyone found a successful way of encouraging employees to share content with their networks (primarily on LinkedIn and Twitter)? I work at a communications agency and we’ve recently invested more in our own brand content - primarily blog posts, webinars and contributed pieces for our executive team. We publish about 2 posts per week and will typically share the links with everyone in Slack with suggestions for copy. While folks are enthusiastic about sharing employee profiles and culture-focused content, they’re less inclined to share pieces about the industry. I’m looking for ways to make sharing easier and/or incentivize it in way that doesn’t feel transactional. Thanks for your help!

elements.text: Has anyone found a successful way of encouraging employees to share content with their networks (primarily on LinkedIn and Twitter)? I work at a communications agency and we’ve recently invested more in our own brand content - primarily blog posts, webinars and contributed pieces for our executive team. We publish about 2 posts per week and will typically share the links with everyone in Slack with suggestions for copy. While folks are enthusiastic about sharing employee profiles and culture-focused content, they’re less inclined to share pieces about the industry. I’m looking for ways to make sharing easier and/or incentivize it in way that doesn’t feel transactional. Thanks for your help!

text: Linkedin has a feature to ‘notify employees’ of a company’s new post - it’s been successful for me in getting people to at least like and even share our content

elements.text: Linkedin has a feature to ‘notify employees’ of a company’s new post - it’s been successful for me in getting people to at least like and even share our content

text:
It's always a struggle. Where I've found some success is to 1) make it clear why it benefits them and/or the company to share the content on social, and 2) make it as easy as possible to share.

You might try sending out direct links to the company's posts on Linkedin/Twitter/etc. so they can just click the link and like/share/comment from there. It takes out some of the friction and effort on their part.

LinkedIn's 'notify employees' feature that <@U01121W33EJ> mentioned is a great tool as well.

elements.text:

You might try sending out direct links to the company's posts on Linkedin/Twitter/etc. so they can just click the link and like/share/comment from there. It takes out some of the friction and effort on their part.

LinkedIn's 'notify employees' feature that
mentioned is a great tool as well.

and
! That’s helpful- we’ve tried sending links to the direct post but not the notify employees feature.

text:
<@U0109E50C78> Beyond making it as easy as possible to share, having someone, especially in a position of power or someone well respected, share a specific win/success story from this can really seal the deal! My company actually makes an employee advocacy tool for social and when I first started I was managing it...just because it was ours didn’t mean people immediately adopted it, it was a new motion. Asking a few internal people to be champions and to give us testimonials of how sharing helped them (especially in sales and success) was so helpful! It sounds very quaint these days but we actually did a poster campaign featuring testimonials from people across the org and it was really well received. Today, I’d take that to Slack, a company newsletter or even better a leadership update where the head of a department recognizes someone who’s built a great personal brand on social thanks to the content you’re curating. 

...I can clearly nerd out about this so feel free to DM if you want to bounce some ideas! I used to lead both content and internal communication, and there’s a lot of great tactics from IC that can help with this.

elements.text:

Asking a few internal people to be champions and to give us testimonials of how sharing helped them (especially in sales and success) was so helpful! It sounds very quaint these days but we actually did a poster campaign featuring testimonials from people across the org and it was really well received. Today, I’d take that to Slack, a company newsletter or even better a leadership update where the head of a department recognizes someone who’s built a great personal brand on social thanks to the content you’re curating. 

...I can clearly nerd out about this so feel free to DM if you want to bounce some ideas! I used to lead both content and internal communication, and there’s a lot of great tactics from IC that can help with this.
